title: Andrea Orcel shows persistence pays . . . handsomely
text:
One thing to start: NSO Group, the Israeli spyware manufacturer whose military-grade Pegasus malware has drawn the scrutiny of human rights groups, is considering a sale or shutdown of the unit, according to two people familiar with the discussions.

Orcel pulls off the gloves 

Andrea Orcel will be the first to admit he isn't one to let things go.

Call it stubbornness or strong will, the kick-boxing banker has proven his stamina in the ring. After a two-and-a-half-year spar over the terms of his former employment with Santander, the now boss of UniCredit has emerged victorious in court.

The rift began in 2019 when Orcel sued the Spanish lender led by Ana Botín for rescinding a job offer to be its new chief executive. The hard-charging Italian punched back, and Santander was ordered to pay Orcel €68m in compensation last week.

The legal affront was especially bold given Orcel's decades-long relationship with the Botín family.

But a courtroom battle — “unfortunate or not” — was “the right thing to do because there was no other way”, Orcel told the FT just before the ruling was announced.

Orcel's persistence hasn't always paid off, however.  

After replacing Jean Pierre Mustier as head of UniCredit earlier this year, one of the new chief's first orders of business was to tick off a long-held priority of UniCredit's chair Pier Carlo Padoan: the takeover of Italy's Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena.

Padoan — the former Italian finance minister — had failed to get the plan past Mustier, who prioritised building UniCredit into a global institution over chasing domestic deals. This was Orcel's chance to exercise politics in his favour.

But after months of negotiations, the plan to carve up MPS went sour. Central to the deal's collapse was a lack of consensus on how much capital the government would be required to inject into MPS.

Orcel, whose €7.5m pay package makes him Italy's highest-paid banker, may have overplayed his hand by demanding a reported €6.5bn from the government to revive the Tuscan lender.

Perhaps Orcel was taking lessons learnt from some of his regrettable deals of the past. He famously advised Royal Bank of Scotland on its disastrous €72bn takeover of the Dutch bank ABN Amro in 2007, which contributed heavily to RBS's collapse.

The MPS debacle has eaten over half of Orcel's time at the helm. Though Orcel hasn't ruled out a future deal for the smaller Italian bank, he must focus on a new strategy.

The path forward doesn't have to involve a new deal. Orcel has already revamped UniCredit's management team, simplified its structure and reduced duplicate roles, and seen profits lift 55 per cent in the third quarter.

As Lex points out, however, the bank's financial gains would likely have prevailed even if Mustier never left. Striking the right deal could help Orcel reclaim the “X Factor” his fans once lauded him for.  

A-Rod: JPMorgan's MVP

Alex Rodriguez might be the most coveted client at JPMorgan Chase.  

The retired baseball star has become a central character in the internal strife at the US banking giant, with different bankers fighting over who gets to manage his multimillion-dollar fortune.

The dispute spilled out into public view after Gwen Campbell, a financial adviser at JPMorgan Advisors, filed for a restraining order against her own employer to prevent what she alleges has been an effort by co-workers at a separate division of JPMorgan to poach her clients, including Rodriguez.

Rodriguez is not named in Campbell's filing but people familiar with the matter told the FT's Josh Franklin that the “Pro Athlete Client” refers to Rodriguez.

Before joining JPMorgan in October last year, Campbell was courted for several months. The process included a conversation with Mary Erdoes, the head of JPMorgan's powerful asset and wealth management division, at A-Rod's Super Bowl party last year.

Campbell is Rodriguez's longtime financial adviser, and alleges that her colleagues at JPMorgan's private bank have been trying to poach him since she joined the Wall Street firm.

The rift highlights a turf war between separate but overlapping business divisions at JPMorgan, which Campbell likened to a “shark tank” — tensions that grew more cut-throat when the bank acquired Bear Stearns during the 2008 financial crisis.

JPMorgan Advisors, the old Bear Stearns financial advisory business where Campbell works, sits within JPMorgan's consumer and community banking division. The private bank sits within the Erdoes-controlled asset and wealth management division.

“You don't feel like you're working at the same company. You feel like you're working at different firms,” said one former JPMorgan private banker.

The Thai conglomerate looking to wrap up Selfridges

DD has been following a deal we hear will be signed in time for the holiday season: Central Group of Thailand, owned by the billionaire Chirathivat family, is poised to buy the UK department store chain Selfridges from the Canadian branch of the Westons.

Early in the sale process, which is being led by Credit Suisse, there were other names circling the asset, such as the private equity group Apollo and Qatari investors.

But after a handshake in London at the beginning of this month, Central and its bankers at Citigroup have been locked in marathon Zoom video calls with the sellers. The aim is to get the deal done before Christmas, according to one party to the sale.

Central already owns some of the poshest names in European top-end retailing: Rinascente in Italy, KaDeWe in Germany and Globus in Switzerland. All that's missing now is a top London store.

The sale price, estimated at about £4bn, would be steep even for one of Thailand's biggest conglomerates. And Central's listed retail unit has faced a rotten year, like the rest of Thai business, thanks to a surge of the Covid-19 Delta variant.  

But as one person close to the sale said, Selfridges is a property of the kind that trades once in a generation.

One way the deal might get done would be for Central to bid together with Signa, the Austrian real estate holding founded by the billionaire René Benko with which it teamed up with to buy Globus.

The keys to Selfridges would be a rich prize for Central, founded by Chinese immigrant Tiang Chirathivat (aka Zheng Ni Tiang) in a shophouse on the wrong side of the Chao Phraya River in Bangkok. The FT's John Reed takes you deeper on the billionaire family here.

Lest anyone wants to get snotty or write off the Thais as parvenus or “dumb money”, it's worth remembering that Harry Gordon Selfridge was a foreigner too (an American) who arrived in London unimpressed by the city's retail scene.

Job moves

  • Francesco De Ferrari, former chief executive of the Australian finance group AMP and Credit Suisse alum, has rejoined the Swiss bank to run its revamped wealth management division.

  • Barclays has appointed Aamir Khan as a managing director in its UK investment banking coverage team. He will join in February from HSBC, where he was a managing director on its M&A team.

  • Barclays has promoted 85 bankers within its corporate and investment banking units to managing director, effective January 1.

  • SVB Financial Group, the parent of Silicon Valley Bank, has acquired the New York-based research firm MoffettNathanson. The group's senior research analysts Craig Moffett, Michael Nathanson and Lisa Ellis and their teams will join SVB as a result.

  • CVC has appointed Jiri Zrust as a partner and head of infrastructure. He will join the private equity group in March from Macquarie Group's infrastructure funds business, where he was most recently a senior managing director and head of energy transition.
